A careless admin leaked half the private key bits during an RSA-encrypted message transit. Can you recover the secret and decrypt 1978539969842661568686913334165659027158002631073925843903546758825345328791333334666403987819317487658709686377729597364362475275078129305541632673026531?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=6425509433190525569571191553532011418280107471352288737504768416116922948232775242802297458671896191346216825032774240320326780433356401325335528752955697, e=4540607103722209779057761212647147587913809131920210005018286960517582481733034567664108687879946758707643465734160389631178871736940829916366803028064569, partial_p=11253921903635606841

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{vxxkxdz7}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 1978539969842661568686913334165659027158002631073925843903546758825345328791333334666403987819317487658709686377729597364362475275078129305541632673026531
vulnerability: partial key exposure
hint: A partial exposure of a prime number's bits can significantly weaken RSA security. Look into lattice-based techniques like Coppersmith's attack.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=6425509433190525569571191553532011418280107471352288737504768416116922948232775242802297458671896191346216825032774240320326780433356401325335528752955697, e=4540607103722209779057761212647147587913809131920210005018286960517582481733034567664108687879946758707643465734160389631178871736940829916366803028064569, partial_p=11253921903635606841
extra_info: p=70642012711217245630175150322259133158891026485945017777788026596616008229897, q=90958753673367787373397259365131627293818024703805461078230669438825068711401, Ï†(n)=6425509433190525569571191553532011418280107471352288737504768416116922948232613642035912873638892618936529434272321531269137029954500382629300087676014400
subtype: partial_key_exposure
